TopicTitle: No RCS, no reaction wheel, no gimball, not enough dV, no good encounter - Eve landing.

Articles.Content:
Sorry, not many pictures - only late into the adventure I got the idea that it makes a good story.

Early in my career I got a contract to test the Ant engine in Sun orbit.

I didn't read the contract carefully and set off to test the engine out of Kerbin SOI and do a near Eve flyby with the very lightweight probe, maybe even test its upper atmosphere. 

![JvfSpHG.png](http://i.imgur.com/JvfSpHG.png)

Stayputnik, the tiny tank, 4 panels, thermometer, barometer and the ANT engine.

All happy, I set course for Eve with the transfer stage, performed the burn for a rather neat encounter (although late, poor alignment = encounter after half of an orbit around the Sun), then separated the probe, dumping the transfer stage with the intent of performing a minimal burn to fulfill the contract requirements.

Well, first the ejection spoiled the neat encounter, and the tiny burn even more, then I noticed the contract specifies an altitude... which falls outside Duna orbit, and then, to my panic, I noticed Ant has no gimball. 

The probe was entirely out of control. No way to turn it, just lots of dV to be used for spoiling the encounter even more.

Oh well, a far flyby is it. I left the probe for half a year of game time, building my empire and conquering Mun and Minmus.

And today the day came when the encounter would occur. A really short, really distant flyby.

As I switched to the probe, to my surprise I noticed one thing: after half a year it still kept the original orientation. Except now, on the other side of the Sun, the nose formerly pointing prograde, was now pointing retrograde!

Not entirely, not accurately, but I had some 500m/s dV more than my current speed.

So, I fired my engines.

A lengthy burn later I spotted I'm no longer going retrograde and burning almost entirely radial. Why? And why is the probe turning? 

Quicksave,because I didn't make one before, and with barely 200m/s more dV than my current speed I set off to solve the puzzle.

Okay. I found it: Ant introduces tiny inaccuracies in its burn. It starts turning in a random direction after a while.

Many quickloads later I got the probe to turn back towards retrograde, then fixed the \*rough\* direction by activating time warp, and quicksaved again. 80m/s of reserve.

Unfortunately with the tank emptied in a significant degree, Ant ceased to produce the "erroneous" pulses. I couldn't turn anymore, and I'd fall short by some 50,000km of Eve, making an orbit but too long to get anything but "In space high". I tried to get an assist for Gilly, but the inclination was all wrong. And all I could do was changing the moment, duration and strength of burn - not its direction. Plus the 80m/s wasn't nearly sufficient to overcome the inaccurate aim.

I discovered that if I delay the burn, the slightly curved flyby path brings the retrograde marker directly into my reticle, maybe a few degrees off. Except that STILL wasn't enough. 10,000km short. 

Then I got to thinking... how my prograde turned into retrograde. How the reticle moved as I waited along the path... could I make any use of it? Would burning prograde be of any use at all?

Eureka! Yes, it would!

Quickload, waiting for the optimal time to burn, and... I allowed the orbit to close, and brought it somewhere within Gilly's orbit but not much farther. Then I warped to periapsis, and - still in the same orientation, unable to turn - burned (mostly) prograde.

I kept burning until the apoapsis left the SOI. Basically, I set an escape trajectory. Except that wasn't all.

![24sUuSv.png](http://i.imgur.com/24sUuSv.png)

Just before reaching Eve escape, I burned again ("mostly retrograde"). But now my orbital speed was far, far lower than on the initial encounter path, even after closing the orbit. The dV left in the tank sufficed with fuel to spare!

A quick lookup at the Wiki: Eve's atmospheric height is 90km. So I set up a periapsis of 85km... and - it worked!

![vrGY1Ed.png](http://i.imgur.com/vrGY1Ed.png)

 The probe survived atmospheric braking and came out with apoapsis a bit beyond Gilly's orbit!

I began totally milking what I had for science. Orbit high, Orbit low and Atmosphere high. 

![WvRRRm4.png](http://i.imgur.com/WvRRRm4.png)

After good dozen orbits, each lower, finally the probe brought the apoapsis into the atmosphere, and began its descent...

![OkD2pig.png](http://i.imgur.com/OkD2pig.png)

Surprisingly, it didn't even overheat...

![acCkUqY.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/acCkUqY.jpg)

Unfortunately, on the night side, Stayputnik's batteries ran out so I couldn't transfer science of atmosphere low, and...

the pressure reduced the 44m/s of dV I had left to zero, and the thick atmosphere was insufficient - 36m/s, but the probe didn't survive.

![husERfh.png](http://i.imgur.com/husERfh.png)

Still, the orbital maneuvers performed without any reasonable ability to turn around - I find it a good reason to brag.
